rComments: This is not a difficult class if you know what Nick wants. Yes the prompts are vauge and he grades hard-based on improvement-but the best way to pass is to go to every class and take detailed notes, you can just regurgitate what he says, add a quote per paragraph and you'll get an A, seriously easy. Plus, how can you not love the Braveheart look?

This class was a complete waste of time. Nick was a good teacher and lecturer, but for being an art history class, we barely looked at actual slides. He taught as if he were teaching a philosophy course and I didn't learn much, if anything at all. The prompts he gave for the papers were always vague, and I never knew where to take them.

People complained about the difficulty in this class, but Morrissey's expectations are realistic considering the depth with which he lectures. He is incredibly intelligent and his approach to the material is fascinating. He presents you with information to think about, rather than pushing his own ideology like many professors do. Great class!

lectures were interesting, but if he was in a bad mood, you could definitely tell in class. was condescending at times, and expected us to be amazing writers on a subject we know nothing about. has 3 written exercises instead of tests, and he expects you to be able to write 2 amazing in class essays. but he grades based on how you improve

A lot of people had a hard time with this class, but I loved his lectures, and we only had three persuasive essays that were open  book/notes/could make outline - why people thought this was hard, I have no idea. LOVED HIM. Made a subject I knew little about really live, rerally fascinating.

The first day I came to class he told me I was going to fail.  His tests are ridiculously hard, as if he expects each person in the class to completely understand the 150 pages of reading the test is on.  We had three written tests which he graded as if we were grad-students, no As were given.  Mostly unpleasant.  I would NOT recommend.
